titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James Reid Parker Papers
titlestmt.author: by Ellen Doon

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:27

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection documents the career of twentieth-century American writer James Reid Parker, including his collaboration with cartoonist Helen E. Hokinson and his trusteeship of her estate. It includes drafts and printed versions of Parker's writings for The New Yorker and Woman's Day, as well as correspondence documenting his professional work, and personal correspondence and papers documenting his family relationships, family history, and military service with the Publications Branch of the Military Intelligence Service during World War II. In addition to correspondence regarding Hokinson's estate, the collection includes approximately forty-five drawings by Hokinson, chiefly for The New Yorker.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Nesheim, 1998.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The James Reid Parker Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James Reid Parker Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: James Reid Parker (1909-1984)
bioghist.p: James Reid Parker was born in Jersey City, New Jersey, on June 2, 1909, to James A. and Rebecca Ives Parker. He received his B.A. from Lafayette College, and an M.A. in English and Comparative Literature from Columbia University in 1931. He became a regular contributor of light humorous pieces to The New Yorker magazine beginning in 1930, and wrote a column entitled "Small World," for Woman's Day from the 1940s to the early 1960s. Many of his New Yorker stories were published as anthologies, including Academic Procession and Attorneys at Law , and he published a novel, The Merry Wives of Massachusetts , in 1959. At The New Yorker , he worked closely with cartoonist Helen E. Hokinson, writing captions for her cartoons from the 1930s until her death in a plane crash in 1949. Parker served as one of the executors and trustees of Hokinson's estate, and as such published a collection of her work entitled The Hokinson Festival in 1956.

Parker married Ruth Lerrigo in 1940, and served in the Army Intelligence Service in Washington during World War II. Following the war, the Parkers lived on Nantucket for some years before moving to New York City. In the 1960s they moved to Hamden, Connecticut, where Parker died on January 27, 1984.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection documents the career of twentieth-century American writer James Reid Parker, including his collaboration with cartoonist Helen E. Hokinson and his trusteeship of her estate. It includes drafts and printed versions of Parker's writings for The New Yorker and Woman's Day , as well as correspondence documenting his professional work, and personal correspondence and papers documenting his family relationships, family history, and military service with the Publications Branch of the Military Intelligence Service during World War II. In addition to correspondence regarding Hokinson's estate, the collection includes approximately forty-five drawings by Hokinson, chiefly for The New Yorker .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Correspondence, 1918-1967. II. Writings, 1919-1991. III. Personal Papers, 1879-1984. IV. Helen E. Hokinson Estate and Artwork, 1925-1990.

controlaccess.title: New Yorker (New York, N.Y. : 1925)
Woman's Day

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I. is arranged alphabetically by correspondent, with one folder of general correspondence filed at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. Correspondence documents Parker's relationships with publishers, with his collaborator Helen Hokinson, and with his family. A significant volume of letters and postcards to his wife document his experiences in Washington, D.C. during World War II. Correspondence with Helen Hokinson includes a series of postcards from Parker containing ideas for captions and cartoons gleaned from overheard conversations on a trip to California, Seattle, and Alaska in 1938. Correspondence with The New Yorker includes pay stubs and contracts.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Additional correspondence is filed with Series II. Writings, and includes exchanges with publishers and fan mail concerning specific works.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II. Writings is arranged alphabetically by title, with some miscellaneous material filed at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. documents Parker's writing career, and includes drafts and printed versions of stories, articles, and plays; correspondence from publishers and fans; contracts for books anthologizing his stories; notebooks; and some early poems and school essays.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes letters from Harold W. Ross and Katharine S. White.

unittitle.title: Attorneys at Law: Forbes, Hathaway, Bryan & Devore

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes letters from Harold W. Ross, Katharine S. White, and Alexander Woollcot.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III. is arranged roughly chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III. Personal Papers consists of legal and financial documents, photographs of Parker (chiefly publicity head shots), and genealogical information. Most extensively documented in this series is Parker's service in the Publications Branch of the Military Intelligence Service during World War II. These papers include a copy of a 1942 report on "The German Campaign in Norway," accompanied by photographs.

did.unittitle: "The Revolutionary Adams Ancestry of Rebecca Ives Parker"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs of family homes and unidentified women.

did.unittitle: "The Queen's Husband," review of dramatic performance
Military service (Military Intelligence Service: Publications Branch)
Tax forms and other financial documentation
Estates of Edmund Parker, James A. Parker, and Lydia Parker
Notes and ephemera from trip to Great Britain
Helen E. Hokinson Estate and Artwork

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV. is arranged by format and size.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV. consists of estate paperwork and drawings. Estate paperwork documents the work of the executors and trustees to disperse and manage Hokinson's assets and to manage the rights to her artwork. It includes information about exhibits of Hokinsons's work and the estate's publication of a compilation of her cartoons, The Hokinson Festival , in 1956. Artwork includes a mix of preliminary sketches, drafts, final versions, and proofs for New Yorker covers and cartoons. Captioned cartoons are chiefly ink and wash drawings, while drawings intended for the cover are watercolors.

did.unittitle: Estate of Helen E. Hokinson, legal correspondence and documents
Cover art for The New Yorker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes sketch published in the July 4, 1925 issue of The New Yorker , and one cartoon not by Hokinson.
